snippet: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that just 44 percent of Americans approve of the job the Supreme Court is doing and three-quarters say the justices’ decisions are sometimes influenced by their personal or political views; findings are a fresh indication that the court’s standing with the public has slipped significantly in the past quarter-century.

byline.original: By ADAM LIPTAK and ALLISON KOPICKI
byline.contributor: Adam Liptak reported from Washington, and Allison Kopicki from New York. Marina Stefan and Dalia Sussman contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.seo: Approval Rating for Supreme Court Hits Just 44% in Poll
headline.main: Approval Rating for Justices Hits Just 44% in New Poll
headline.print_headline: Approval Rating For Justices Hits just 44% In Poll

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
